head.supplied: [Bombala, 20 June 1887] ¶ ¶ [...] ¶ ¶ Amongst the Herbarium Specimens you will find two totally different species of Eucalypts named Euc. Gunnii. The one with the broad leaves is the spec. of which ...

div.p: MRS 202/171 special bundle, collector, Archives of the Museum of Applied Arts and Sciences, Ultimo, New South Wales.

Amongst the Herbarium Specimens you will find two totally different species of Eucalypts named Euc. Gunnii. The one with the broad leaves is the spec. of which I have sent you Leaves, Bark and a small quantity of Gum, and of which you will also receive a log. Some time ago I wrote that the specific name must be looked upon as provisional only, but since that the Baron has determined it to be Euc. Gunnii by budding and fruiting specimens I sent him from Delegate. I am sorry two fruiting specimens I laid by for you, were by inadvertance thrown out, which I found out only after I had left Delegate, but the shape of the flowerbuds will show you already that it is quite different from the other species obtained on the top of Tingiringi, which there does not grow to tree size and attains a height only of about 15f. The fruit of this species is quite different from the other. Flowers I am sorry could not be obtained at this time of the year neither from the one nor the other. Even should there be a similarity in the anthers of those two Eucalypts, when we get the flowers, then I can scarcely believe that they are mere varieties of the same species.
